text: Hey Steph, what has worked REALLY well for us at The Predictive Index is doing original research (we do quarterly research reports) then using those data insights to inform webinar topics. So we do 4 co-marketing webinars a year where industry experts dive into the data insights. At the end of each webinar we ask people to raise their hand if they are interested in a demo, and we have gotten as many as 147 hand raisers! Do you do original research? (I have a course on it if you/your company is interested.)

elements.text: Hey Steph, what has worked REALLY well for us at The Predictive Index is doing original research (we do quarterly research reports) then using those data insights to inform webinar topics. text:
I’m not sure what you mean by organize this, so feel free to clarify. What’s important here is a) alignment and b) scale. 

Meetings help you stay aligned, but many times they’re inefficient (could have been a Loom video). 

Are you using async channels to stay aligned (Slack channel, Loom videos, etc.)? 

Are you using a form to collect ideas—and does it automatically populate into your project management software so you’re not manually adding it? 

Are you building your content strategy alongside the overarching marketing strategy and customer success strategy—so you’re working toward common goals?

Etc.

text: Looking for tips and advice on how to get case studies approved with our customers fast. Right now it's the holidays and reviewing a draft of a case study probably isn't on the top of their to-do list. Are there any particular strategies that have worked well for you?

elements.text: Looking for tips and advice on how to get case studies approved with our customers fast. Right now it's the holidays and reviewing a draft of a case study probably isn't on the top of their to-do list. Are there any particular strategies that have worked well for you?

text: For us we simply were honest with them. “Hi, we need this case study approved quickly due to the holiday rush. Would you be able to help us out?”

elements.text: For us we simply were honest with them. “Hi, we need this case study approved quickly due to the holiday rush. Would you be able to help us out?”

text:
Hey Steph! When I was at AlayaCare, we started offering monthly "platform tours" narrated by a Sales Engineer. The live tour would cover one main feature or market - e.g. mobile app, skilled nursing, etc for about 45 minutes. We would graduate anyone who attended to an MQL and it was a very good source of pipeline for people who actually wanted personalized demos.

As an extra bonus, the recordings were very helpful for BDRs or AEs looking to send an overview of a certain product aspect that their leads could share with another team member who may have had objections.

elements.text:
Hey Steph! When I was at AlayaCare, we started offering monthly "platform tours" narrated by a Sales Engineer. The live tour would cover one main feature or market - e.g. mobile app, skilled nursing, etc for about 45 minutes. We would graduate anyone who attended to an MQL and it was a very good source of pipeline for people who actually wanted personalized demos.

As an extra bonus, the recordings were very helpful for BDRs or AEs looking to send an overview of a certain product aspect that their leads could share with another team member who may have had objections.

text:
I always make it about them, not me. And I always give a reasonable amount of time (two weeks). Is there REALLY a reason you need it ASAP? Prob not.

Something like “I know the holidays are an extremely busy time of year for you, so please don’t stress yourself out trying to review this right away. If you could take a peek and let me know if it’s approved by the end of next week (date), that would be amazing!”

elements.text:

text: If you can offer a discount (e.g. on a future renewal) for review by EOY, that can definitely help!

elements.text: If you can offer a discount (e.g. on a future renewal) for review by EOY, that can definitely help!

text:
This won’t help with the ones already in progress, but this is what has helped:
• Advocacy/case study clause in contract, usually tied to price negotiations or other concessions they’ve requested at signing or renewal. Obviously the customer still has to agree, approve, etc. but if they’re contractually obligated it becomes much easier and faster.
• Talk about approval processes and timelines with your champion up front. Can they review and approve on their own, or do they need to run it up the ladder? Who all has to approve? What gets things stuck in the process? etc.
• Get them to at least verbally agree to a rough statement of facts before you submit the full case study for approval. Maybe this is an unnecessary extra step at some orgs, but I find it’s helpful especially in enterprise contexts where the champion has to do a lot of work to get something approved. If they agree, at least in principle, that the story/facts are solid, it’s unlikely they’ll change course later on.

elements.text: This won’t help with the ones already in progress, but this is what has helped:

Advocacy/case study clause in contract, usually tied to price negotiations or other concessions they’ve requested at signing or renewal. Obviously the customer still has to agree, approve, etc. but if they’re contractually obligated it becomes much easier and faster.

Talk about approval processes and timelines with your champion up front. Can they review and approve on their own, or do they need to run it up the ladder? Who all has to approve? What gets things stuck in the process? etc.

Get them to at least verbally agree to a rough statement of facts before you submit the full case study for approval. Maybe this is an unnecessary extra step at some orgs, but I find it’s helpful especially in enterprise contexts where the champion has to do a lot of work to get something approved. If they agree, at least in principle, that the story/facts are solid, it’s unlikely they’ll change course later on.

text: We also experimented a bit with a sort of Office hours / small workshops on dedicated strategic topics (open to our audience, but with a prequalifying subscription form) > we made them on demand to be sure to match people (no more than 5) and facilitated them (so they had a theme to work on and concrete results, tailored for their business problem).

text:
Include a good chunk of challenges, and use the gratitude bits or the "flex" bits as mirrors to them. Spend a good amount of time tagging specific people for things.

e.g.

Five people quit, and we could have done better to keep them. But we still managed to hit 10% above projection thanks to the rest of the crew stepping up. Major shout out to [at-someone].

text: Hey <@U027ESP05FX> - how did they perform for you? Was it worth the cost? How did you promote them? Thanks!!

- how did they perform for you? Was it worth the cost? How did you promote them? Thanks!!

text:
I found more success when we did the cool vendor report we were featured in vs. when we hosted some of their more general thought leadership options. We definitely did a much bigger push around the cool vendor - paid ads, paid and organic social, email promo, a press release, blog, etc.

A challenge we ran into with some of the other content was that I was at a smaller company so a lot of their content mentioned our competitors and not us, and there weren't always great options to choose from.

elements.text:
I found more success when we did the cool vendor report we were featured in vs. when we hosted some of their more general thought leadership options. We definitely did a much bigger push around the cool vendor - paid ads, paid and organic social, email promo, a press release, blog, etc.

A challenge we ran into with some of the other content was that I was at a smaller company so a lot of their content mentioned our competitors and not us, and there weren't always great options to choose from.

text: If your company is mentioned in a cool vendor report, magic quadrant, or the like, and that's something that can make you stand out and attract attention, then I think it can be worth it. If you're just looking for some sponsored content to drive leads, I don't think their reprints are as worthy but it might depend on the industry and audience.

elements.text: If your company is mentioned in a cool vendor report, magic quadrant, or the like, and that's something that can make you stand out and attract attention, then I think it can be worth it. If you're just looking for some sponsored content to drive leads, I don't think their reprints are as worthy but it might depend on the industry and audience.

text:
these are great ideas — another one that has helped me in the past is enlisting a higher-up to chime in to express their excitement on the project. so less about “please review this by XX” but more “Phillip told me all about this case study, we are thrilled to have you involved and are so grateful for your partnership. Please reach out to us if you or your team have any questions”

it’s funny how an email from a VP or higher can get folks to respond and follow up :smirk: (much to my chagrin, haha)

text:
*Most B2B brand get their narrative all wrong — especially when it comes to video content.* The biggest mistake? Your company/product is NOT the protagonist of your story... your CUSTOMERS are.

*A template that all of us can steal: Make your persona feel like heroes for using your product.*

Just worked on an awesome video campaign for Privy that’s a perfect example of this :arrow_down:
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hq9gjbWwawY> 

And btw, this also works as a killer ABM strategy. Want to make your target accounts feel special? Have a video crew follow them around for a day and make docu-style content that makes *them* the hero.

attachments.video_html: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Hq9gjbWwawY?feature=oembed&autoplay=1&iv_load_policy=3" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>
attachments.fallback: YouTube Video: This Is The Age Of The Founder | Privy
